awd_titl_txt: EAGER: High Performance Algorithms and Implementatations for Genome Alignment
awd_abstract_narration:
Analysis of biological sequences, including multiple sequence alignment, motif finding, and genome alignment, is a fundamental problem in computational biology due to its critical significance in wide ranging applications including haplotype reconstruction, sequence homology, phylogenetic analysis, and prediction of evolutionary origins. Most of the sequence analysis problem formulations (particularly those related to alignment) are considered NP-hard. Existing solutions to the sequence alignment problem (both sequential as well as parallel) are extremely limited in their applicability and yield poor performance for large data sets. Moreover most of these solutions have been designed for aligning short length sequences. The genome alignment problem (very long sequences) is significantly harder and very few solutions exist that are capable to construct genomes from short reads while taking significant amount of execution time. This project deals with the design and development of high performance algorithms and implementations for aligning genomes using innovative sampling and domain decomposition strategies. This approach has never been pursued for genome alignment in the past. The proposed algorithms are implemented on hybrid computing platforms consisting of multicore clusters and GPU units.

This project brings together tools and applications from multiple disciplines such as bioinformatics, computational biology, statistics, and high performance computing. Therefore the findings will introduce new tools for biology and biomedical applications. It will facilitate rapid reconstruction of genomes and mapping of short reads to the corresponding haplotypes.

por.por_cntn:
Analysis of biological sequences, including multiple sequence alignment, motif finding, and genome alignment, is a fundamental problem in computational biology due to its critical significance in wide ranging applications including haplotype reconstruction, sequence homology, phylogenetic analysis, and prediction of evolutionary origins. Most of the sequence analysis problem formulations (particularly those related to alignment) are computationally complex and take unrealistically long time to get solved on ordinary computers. In this project we have pursued the design and development of solutions for such problems on high performance computing platforms that employ multiple processors and GPUs.

 

The project has designed novel sampling and decomposition techniques to splice the sequence analysis problems to be solved on multiprocessor platforms. It has also developed new metrics to compute the similarity of sequences in the input that has been further used to achieve load-balanced partitions of the problem. These techniques have been further extended to solve problems in proteomics, particularly those related to mass spectra analysis and peptide identification. The proposed research has developed new high-performance algorithms for the analysis of large number sequences and mass spectra’s. The implemented algorithms are available as open-source tools via PI webpages.

 

The proposed solutions have benefitted disciplines such as bioinformatics, computational biology, and high performance computing. Also, these solutions have been shared with peers via conferences presentations and archival journal papers. Graduate, undergraduate students have been trained to pursue professional careers in this high tech markets.
